channel.title: Guitar recording software
channel.description:
Well, I bought a cable that connects my headphone output of my guitar amp with my mic input of my laptop so I can record what I play in better quality. I currently use soundrecorder. But putting a cable in the amp obviously stops the amp from outputting sound from it's loudspeaker. So I can't hear what I play until I finished recording it. Is there any program that allows you to record and hear your guitar play at the same time?
Thanks in advance.

item.title: Guitar recording software
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

On another topic

There’s a 6.3mm jack port on my amp that just says Out underneath it. If I connect that up to anything it outputs a fairly quiet sound. Maybe yours has one?

That’s the one I use. But anyways, I’m thinking of buying a flattop steelstring whatever accoustic guitar because I just love the sound of Robert Johnson.

Read full topic

item.title: Guitar recording software
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

Ah yes, that was quite obvious

What I can try is to use my headphones, they can amplify a bit so I can still hear it. If that won’t work I’ll look into a USB line in.

Thanks Mopman.

Read full topic

item.title: Guitar recording software
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

That is what is wrong with putting it in the mic in The mic in is for signals that need amplication, you are putting an already hot signal into it. It needs to go into a line-level input to get proper quality.

Of course, it is possible your laptops sound card just sucks.

Your best option would be to get a cheap audio interface, perhaps a USB one. Or like I said, go without the amp for now and buy/torrent some amp modelling software, there is some pretty fun stuff around

Read full topic

item.title: Guitar recording software
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

What’s wrong with putting it into the mic in? I must say that the quality isn’t really what I expected it to be. I can’t hear it when it’s on my normal volume, and when I raise the volume on the amp the quality sucks.

Read full topic

item.title: Guitar recording software
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

R.I.P RSC:

I don’t have a line in on my laptop. All I have is a mic in and a headphone out.

Then plug the guitar in directly (no amp) and use amp modelling software like Guitar Rig, or get a cheap audio interface with a line level in. You shouldnt go amp->mic in.

Read full topic

item.title: Guitar recording software
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

I don’t have a line in on my laptop. All I have is a mic in and a headphone out.

Anyways, I fixed it by changing some settings off my loudspeakers. I previously tried to change it via the MIC settings but that didn’t work. Thanks Mopman for pointing me in the direction.

Read full topic

item.title: Guitar recording software
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Well, first of all, you want to plug the cable from your amp into the LINE IN on your soundcard, not the MIC IN.

Then you need to play with the Windows mixer to enable the sound to come out of your speakers, because it should.

As for better recording apps, if you just want a simple multitrack recorder/editer, no MIDI or anything like that, take a look at http://audacity.sourceforge.net - it’s pretty good for a freebie.

Read full topic
